title: 111_hr5618
content: The Act may be cited as the "Restoration of Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2010" and includes an extension of unemployment insurance provisions. The text chunk discusses amendments to various sections related to unemployment benefits, changing dates from June 2, 2010, to later dates in 2010 and 2011. The Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2008 is amended to change the date from November 6, 2010, to April 30, 2011. Funding conditions for receiving Emergency Unemployment Compensation are also amended. The amendments made by this section, including terms and conditions related to availability for work, active search for work, and refusal to accept work, shall take effect as if included in the enactment of the Continuing Extension Act of 2010. SEC. 3. COORDINATION OF EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION WITH REGULAR COMPENSATION. Section 4002 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 is amended to coordinate emergency unemployment compensation with regular compensation for individuals who qualify for a new benefit year with specific weekly benefit amounts. The State determines eligibility for compensation based on weekly benefit amount. For individuals qualifying for a new benefit year, the State decides between emergency unemployment compensation or regular compensation for a week of unemployment. The State may establish a new benefit year but delay regular compensation until emergency unemployment compensation is exhausted. The State may defer establishing a new benefit year until emergency unemployment compensation is exhausted. If permitted by State law, regular compensation can be paid equal to the weekly benefit amount under the new benefit year. The amendment allows for emergency unemployment compensation to be provided to individuals whose benefit years expire after the enactment of the Act. The State can determine eligibility for emergency compensation independently of regular compensation if the individual chooses not to file for regular benefits in the new benefit year. States must not reduce regular compensation to be eligible for funds under the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program. Section 4001 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 prohibits states from reducing regular compensation to qualify for Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program funds. The Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 prohibits states from reducing regular compensation to qualify for Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program funds. The average weekly benefit amount of regular compensation during a specific period will be less than the amount payable under the State law as of June 2, 2010. SEC. 5. PROCEDURES. Section 4001 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 is amended to include procedures for states with agreements under the Act to prevent benefits from being provided to known or suspected terrorists, individuals convicted of sex offenses against minors, and unauthorized aliens. The section aims to prevent unauthorized aliens from receiving emergency unemployment compensation under the Act. SEC. 6. BUDGETARY PROVISIONS. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. Sections 2 and 3 are designated as emergency requirements under different provisions in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Requirement under section 403(a) of S. Con. Res. 13 (111th Congress) for fiscal year 2010 budget. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 1, 2010. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
